children.text: L.1 Follow simple and complex directions
Demonstrate understanding through non-verbal gestures or with single words or learned phrases
Follow simple two-step oral directions to complete a task in English
Interpret gestures and visual cues used in instruction
Perform basic classroom tasks when prompted
Follow simple three or four-step oral directions to complete a classroom task
Restate and execute multi-step oral directions
Respond appropriately and courteously to directions and questions
Perform most uncomplicated classroom tasks when prompted
Clarify classroom assignments with teacher and/or peers
L.2 Understand spoken English to participate in social contexts
Understand highly contextualized simple speech with frequent repetition and rephrasing
Understand basic language such as, greetings, leave-taking, questions, and directions
Understand simple speech produced by peers and adults on familiar topics with repetition and rephrasing
Understand age-appropriate social discourse with occasional repetition and rephrasing
Understand ageappropriate social discourse
Respond to messages by asking questions, challenging statements or offering examples that affirm the message
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language and idiomatic expressions by responding to and using such expressions appropriately
L.3 Identify main ideas and supporting details from spoken English
Use active listening comprehension in a variety of situations such as following directions, responding to requests, and listening for specific purposes
Listen attentively to stories and information read aloud
Demonstrate comprehension of oral presentations and instructions through nonverbal responses
Listen and respond to stories and other texts read aloud, including classic and contemporary works
Orally identify main points of simple conversations and stories read aloud
Understand the major ideas and supporting evidence in spoken messages
Identify some supporting details from a variety of media messages
Listen attentively to stories/information and identify key details and concepts using both verbal and non-verbal responses
Identify the main idea and some supporting details of oral presentations, familiar literature, and key concepts of subject matter content
Identify main ideas and fact versus fiction in broadcast media
Listen attentively to stories or content information and identify key details and concepts using both verbal and written responses
Critique accuracy and intent of media presentation
Listen attentively to more complex stories/information on new topics across content areas in order to identify the main points and supporting details

Listen and respond appropriately to presentations and performances of peer or published works such as original essays or narratives, interpretations of poetry, or individual or group performances of scripts
L.4 Identify meaning of vocabulary in the content areas
Understand limited key content area vocabulary supported by visual representations and realia (real-life objects)
Understand key content area vocabulary supported by visuals and written text provided during classroom instruction
Understand vocabulary and discourse features of content areas
Use knowledge of language and develop content area vocabulary to support comprehension of the speaker's message
Take accurate notes based on classroom instruction; clarify questions regarding information with peers or teacher; and/or clarify from text or other references
L.5 Identify speaker attitude and point of view
Demonstrate understanding of speaker's feelings and attitudes toward a topic
Use age-appropriate social conventions that characterize the new culture while listening, such as eye contact, physical proximity, and turn-taking
Interpret speaker's messages, purposes, and perspectives
Listen critically to interpret and evaluate
Evaluate a spoken message in terms of its content, credibility and delivery
Identify the main ideas, points of view, and fact/fiction in broadcast and print media
Identify strategies presented by the media to present information for various purposes, such as perform, entertain or persuade
L.6 Make inferences and predictions
Respond to the implications of tones of voice
Infer speaker's implied meaning
Infer speaker's messages, purposes, and perspectives
Demonstrate proficiency in each aspect of the listening process such as focusing attention, interpreting, and perspectives
Differentiate fact and opinion on topics or issues presented by broadcast media
S.1 Use spoken language for daily activities within and beyond the school setting
Use learned phrases to respond to questions and directions
Make requests and obtain information from the community
Participate in conversations on social topics by asking and requesting information
Acquire goods, services, or information by spoken request
Draw conclusions from interactions with individuals from other cultures
S.2 Engage in conversations for personal expression and enjoyment
Communicate basic wants and needs in English
Use common social greetings and simple repetitive phrases
Participate in social conversations with peers and adults on familiar topics by asking and answering questions and requesting information
Participate in social conversations with peers and adults on unfamiliar topics by asking and answering questions and restating and requesting information
Demonstrate understanding of idiomatic expressions by responding to and using them appropriately
Negotiate and initiate social conversations by questioning, restating, requesting information and paraphrasing the communication of others
Talk about experiences using expanded vocabulary, descriptive words and paraphrasing
S.3 Use spoken English and nonverbal communication in socially and culturally appropriate ways
Maintain eye contact when communicating in person
Recognize some gestures, facial expressions and body language
Understand and interpret the significance of gestures, facial expressions, and body language
Produce appropriate gestures, facial expressions and body language
Use idiomatic expressions appropriately
Vary speech according to purpose, audience and subject matter
S.4 Use English to interact in the classroom
Recite rhymes, songs and simple stories
Respond orally to factual questions
Ask and respond to questions using phrases or simple sentences
Participate in classroom discussions
Restate in basic terms the main idea of oral presentations using subject area content
Ask and answer instructional questions using simple sentences
Give directions or instructions to classmates
Participate in guided discussions
Give simple oral reports
Participate actively in cooperative group activities and projects
Participate actively in content area discussions with peers and teachers
Exchange, support, and discuss opinions and individual perspectives with peers on a variety of topics dealing with content area information or issues
S.5 Provide and obtain information; express and exchange opinions
Answer instructional questions by using simple sentences
Answer instructional questions with supporting details
Respond to messages by asking questions, challenging statements, or offering examples that affirm the message
Talk about experiences using expanded vocabulary, descriptive words and paraphrasing
Negotiate and initiate conversations by questioning, restating, requesting information, and paraphrasing the communication of others
S.6 Demonstrate comprehensible pronunciation and intonation for clarity in oral communication
Use clearly spoken single words and learned phrases to be understood by a native speaker
Speak understandably with awareness of English intonation and phonological patterns
Speak clearly and comprehensibly by using standard English grammatical forms, pronunciation, phrasing and intonation
Demonstrate control of the English phonological system and patterns of intonation when conversing with a native speaker in spontaneous situations
S.7 Present information, concepts, and ideas to an audience of listeners on a variety of topics
Describe a concrete object or concept with prepared text
Prepare and deliver short oral presentations
Retell stories and participate in short conversations
Prepare and deliver short presentations on ideas, images and topics obtained from various common sources
Prepare and ask basic interview questions and respond to them
Prepare and deliver presentations and reports in various content areas, including a purpose, point of view, introduction, coherent transitions, and appropriate conclusions
S.8 Use strategies to extend communicative competence
Use gestures for clarification and to support communication
Ask for clarification and repetition
Identify orally the main points of simple conversations and stories that are read aloud
Make requests relevant to the teaching learning process (homework instructions)
Formulate and pose questions during classroom discussions
Respond to messages by asking questions or by challenging statements
Summarize orally with accurate representation of the content of the conversation
R.1 Recognize concepts of print literacy
Demonstrate initial print awareness that print carries message
Know the order of the alphabet; name and identify each letter of the alphabet
Know the difference between capital and lower case letters
Distinguish letters from words
Demonstrate directionality by tracking print from left to right, and using return sweep
Recognize that sentences in print are made up of separate words
Recognize that words have correct spelling
Identify the front cover, back cover, and title page of a book
Understand that printed materials provide information
Use knowledge of simple spelling patterns when reading
Recognize capitalization and punctuation to convey meaning
R.2 Demonstrate phonological awareness and the relationship of listening/speaking to decoding
Demonstrate that print represents spoken language
Understand that as letters change, so do sounds
Use knowledge of consonants and vowels sounds to match sounds to letters
Use knowledge of consonants, consonant blends, and vowel sounds in decoding words
Read common word families and rhyming words
Use decoding skills to read known and unfamiliar words
Match oral words to printed words
R.3 Build vocabulary to develop concepts
Recognize high frequency words
Develop basic sight words
Use context clues as a strategy to figure out meaning of unfamiliar words and phrases
Use meaning clues and language structure to expand vocabulary (pictures, background knowledge, context clues)
Apply knowledge of letter-sound correspondences, language structure, and context to recognize words
Identify simple words with multiple meanings
Identify simple literary terms (title, author, illustrator)
Recognize common cognates
Demonstrate knowledge of prefixes and suffixes, root, antonyms, homonyms, synonyms and abbreviations to determine meaning
Recognize words that have multiple meanings in literature and texts in content areas
Recognize simple idioms and figures of speech
Identify simple literary terms across a variety of genre (title, author, illustrator)
Use knowledge of cognates and false cognates when reading
Recognize simple analogies and metaphors in literature and texts in content areas
R.4 Understand and use grammatical structures of English to improve reading comprehension
Identify nouns and verbs (subjects and predicates)
Recognize basic English syntax (sentence structure) and grammar to derive meaning
Use knowledge of complex syntax (sentence structure) and grammatical features to derive meaning from narrative text
Apply knowledge of complex syntax (sentence structure) and advanced grammatical features to derive meaning from content area texts
R.5 Read and demonstrate comprehension of main idea and supporting details
Name characters and identify setting of story
Recognize the beginning, middle and end of narratives
Answer factual, simple questions about content of text
Participate in discussions describing characters, setting, events and plot
Identify the topic or main idea of text
Restate facts and details of text
Distinguish between fact and opinion in informational text
Summarize informational or narrative selections
Compare and contrast characters; describe setting and events in text
Demonstrate knowledge of story structure and sequence
Describe the development of plot and identify how conflicts are addressed and resolved
Recognize the theme (general observation about life and human nature) within a text
Identify main ideas and supporting details from grade appropriate texts
R.6 Apply reading skills in social and academic contexts
Identify common signs and logos
Use prior background knowledge to approach text
Use print from the environment to derive and reinforce meaning
Read and follow simple written directions
Use simple reference materials (such as picture dictionaries) to acquire concepts
Locate pictures, maps, keys, charts, tables, graphs, diagrams, chapter headings, and table of contents
Read and follow sequential or multiple step written directions to complete tasks and assignments
Use simple reference materials to acquire concepts (dictionary, thesaurus, technologies, vocabulary categories, and alphabetical order)
Use text features such as illustrations, diagrams, charts, glossaries, and indexes to draw information from text
Use strategies to read text (preview, predict, question while reading, reread, and self-correct)
Apply information using table of contents, index, and chapter headings, diagrams, keys, charts, tables, pictures, maps, graphs and glossary
Make connections between prior knowledge, personal experiences and what is read
R.7 Read for research purposes
Develop questions about a topic
Collect and organize information using a resource other than the textbook for presentations and/or projects
Collect and organize information from multiple resources for presentations and/or projects
Evaluate and synthesize information from multiple sources for use in presentations and/or projects
R.8 Make inferences, predictions, and conclusions from reading
Use pictures/graphics to make predictions about text, and discuss conclusions
Use pictures to make predictions about stories and informational text
Make and confirm predictions about the subject/story from text clues
Draw conclusions from information provided in the text
Draw inferences about stories read aloud and use simple phrases to communicate the inferences
Read text and use detailed sentences to identify orally the main ideas and use them to make predictions supported by details
Read text and use detailed sentences to identify orally the main ideas and use them to make predictions with supporting details about informational text, literary text, and text in content areas
R.9 Analyze style and form of various genre
Identify elements of a story, including character, setting, and sequence of events
Recognize format differences between poetry and prose
Recognize differences between expository and narrative text
Use graphic displays (photos, art, pictures, icons, symbols) and textual aides (sub-heading, graphs, charts) to understand stories and informational text
Demonstrate knowledge of story structure and sequence
Differentiate between fiction and non-fiction
Understand literary forms by recognizing and distinguishing among stories, poems, and information books
Distinguish between reality and fantasy in literature
Understand literary forms by recognizing and distinguishing among stories, poems, myths, fables, tall tales, plays, biographies, autobiographies, and historical fiction
Use text structure or sequence of ideas such as cause/effect or chronology to recall information
Distinguish between explicit examples of fact, opinion, and cause/effect in text
Determine whether the evidence in a text supports a conclusion
Identify information from graphic displays and textual aides
Understand literary forms by recognizing and distinguishing among short essays, novels, journals, informational text
Discuss significant structural patterns in text such as, compare/contrast, sequence or chronological order, and cause/effect
Analyze a variety of rhetorical styles found in consumer and informational materials
Analyze characteristics of text including its structure, word choices and intended audiences
Judge the internal consistency or logic of stories and texts, such as Would this character do this? Does this action make sense here?
Describe how graphic displays and textual aids convey meaning
Analyze the features and rhetorical devices of public documents and primary source material
Distinguish elements of literary technique (foreshadowing, flashbacks, figurative language, dialogue, metaphor, simile)
Identify literacy devices narrative voice, symbolism, dialect, and irony
Analyze text for the purpose, ideas and style of the author
Read and analyze how clarity is affected by patterns of organization, repetition of key ideas, syntax, and word choice
Critique the effectiveness of graphic displays and textual aids
R.10 Identify author's voice, attitude and point of view
Understand that authors write for different purposes such as persuading, informing, entertaining and instructing
Distinguish personal opinions and points of view from that of the author and support with examples
Describe how the author's perspective or point of view affects the text
Analyze text for the voice of the author
Recognize how style, tone and mood contribute to the effect of the text
W.1 Use conventions and formats of written English
Write the English alphabet legibly in manuscript (printing) using upper and lower case
Write messages from left to right and top to bottom of the page
Use word and letter spacing to make messages readable
Write personal information (name, address, phone number)
Write labels, notes and captions for illustrations, charts, and objects
Write words and short sentences from dictation with developmental spelling
Copy from a model text with attention to using lines, margins, and spacing
Write several sentences on a topic related to a visual prompt
Write the English alphabet legibly in cursive using upper and lower case
Write sentences from dictation with more conventional spelling of familiar words
Write simple sentences using key words available in the classroom environment
Organize and record expository information on pictures, lists, charts and tables from information presented in the classroom
Write several sentences on a topic in paragraph format using indentation
Write with consistent use of spelling patterns and rules
Organize, record and summarize expository information for posters and presentations for literature and content areas subjects
Write three paragraphs including a beginning, middle and end on a prompt/theme
Use resources to edit text for consistently correct spelling
Write an essay or narrative demonstrating control of paragraph formation
W.2 Use grammatical conventions of English
Use capitalization and punctuation to begin and end sentences
Use nouns (singulars and plurals), verbs (singular and plural), pronouns, adjectives, adverbs in writing
Use basic grammatical constructions in simple sentences
Capitalize and punctuate correctly to clarify and enhance meaning (such as capitalizing titles, using possessives, commas in a series, apostrophes and contractions, and abbreviations)
Identify and correctly use subject verb agreement and past, present, and future tenses in writing simple sentences
Demonstrate knowledge of negatives and contractions
Demonstrate knowledge of verbs, tenses and modals (auxiliaries), WH-words and pronouns and antecedents
Demonstrate knowledge of parts of speech
Use punctuation and capitalization to enhance meaning and express complex thoughts (such as direct quotes and compound sentences)
Use a variety of parts of speech to clarify writing
Use prepositional phrases to elaborate written ideas
Demonstrate knowledge of nominative, objective, and possessive case
Use verb tenses appropriately in present, past, future, perfect and progressive
Use punctuation and capitalization to enhance meaning and express complex thoughts to produce complex sentences without sentence fragments or run-on sentences
Demonstrate control over grammatical elements, subject-verb agreement, pronoun-antecedent agreement, verbs forms, transitions and parallel construction
Use clauses, phrases and mechanics with consistent variation in grammatical forms
W.3 Write using appropriate vocabulary choice and variation
Use descriptive vocabulary to clarify details
Use thematic and content-specific vocabulary introduced in the classroom for writing across the curriculum
Select words from an expanded personal vocabulary to accurately communicate ideas clearly and concisely across the curriculum

Use vocabulary to convey intended meaning while recognizing the meanings and cultural uses of the other registers in English which are often expressed through colloquialisms, idioms, and other language forms
W.4 Construct sentences and develop paragraphs to organize writing supporting a central idea
Compose simple declarative, interrogative, imperative, and exclamatory sentences appropriate for language arts and other content areas based on a classroom model
Compose multiple sentences around a topic
Support a central idea with relevant details and examples
Write a brief expository composition that includes a thesis and some supporting details
Use resources to extend vocabulary choices in writing (bilingual dictionary, thesaurus, English dictionary)
Independently create cohesive paragraphs that develop a central idea with consistent use of standard English grammatical forms, including a variety of sentence types
Use varied sentence structure to express meaning and achieve desired effect
Produce cohesive and coherent written text by organizing ideas, using effective transitions, and choosing precise wording
Organize ideas in writing to ensure coherence, logical progression, and support for ideas
Use effective sequences and transitions to achieve coherence and meaning
Produce a multiple paragraph essay that elaborates a thesis
Structure ideas and arguments within a defined context including supporting and relevant examples
W.5 Use the writing process to produce writing
Prewriting: Generate ideas for writing by using prewriting techniques such as drawing and teacher assisted listing of key thoughts
Drafting: Develop drafts by categorizing ideas and organizing them into sentences with teacher assistance
Editing: Edit writing for punctuation, capitalization and spelling with teacher assistance; create legible final copy
Prewriting: Use graphic organizers as a prewriting activity to demonstrate prior knowledge, add information and prepare to write
Drafting: Use simple sentences to follow an outline or graphic organizer to create a draft of a paragraph
Revising: Revise draft by elaborating text with expanded use of adjectives, adverbs and a variety of sentence structures
Revising: Revise writing for expanded word choice and organization with variation in grammatical forms
Editing: Edit draft for basic grammatical constructions; expand use of adjectives and adverbs; check for singular and plural agreement
Prewriting: Plan ideas through independent organizing activities such as listing, webbing, clustering, sequencing, and classifying in English
Drafting: Develop a draft by organizing ideas into sentences and paragraphs following an organizational plan
Revising: Revise writing by adding, elaborating, combining, deleting, and rearranging text
Editing: Edit writing to ensure use of grammar conventions
Prewriting: Use planning strategies to organize information, generate ideas, and develop voice
Drafting: Develop a draft independently by organizing and reorganizing content and by refining style to suit occasion, audience and purpose
Revising: Revise writing for appropriate word choice, consistent point of view, introductions, transitions, and conclusions
Editing: Edit writing for developmentally appropriate syntax, spelling, grammar, usage, and punctuation
W.6 Use various types of writing for specific purposes
Write basic information on classroom assignments, such as, name, date, class subject, teacher
Write to communicate basic personal information such as filling out forms, autobiographical sketches, home-culture descriptions
List, label, or summarize content area information
Write a few words or phrases about an event or character from a story read by the teacher
Write a short narrative story that includes elements of setting and character
Write in different forms for different purposes including lists to inform, letters to invite or thank, and stories to entertain
Write brief responses to selected literature with factual understanding of the text using simple sentences
Write a brief narrative include elements of setting, character, and events
Narrate a sequence of events with some detail
Write friendly letters, formal letters, thank you letters, and invitations that address audience concerns, stated purpose and context using conventional letter formats
Write across the curriculum with teacher assistance stories and other compositions such as personal narratives, journal entries, friendly poems in English
Write simple compositions such as descriptions, compare/contrast that have a main idea and some supporting details
Write technical materials such as instructions for performing tasks or playing a game that include specific details
Write responses to selected literature that exhibit understanding of the text, using detailed sentences and transitions
Use the writing process to write brief narratives using standard grammatical forms
Write simple compositions that address a single topic that include supporting sentences with concrete sensory details of people, places, things or experiences
Write in various forms with particular emphasis on business forms such as a report, memo, narrative or procedure, summary/abstract, and resume
Write a brief expository composition that includes a thesis and some points of support; provide information from primary sources; organize and record information on charts and graphs
Write short expository text that proposes a solution to a problem or speculates on causes and effects
Write responses to selected literature that develop interpretations, exhibit careful reading, and cite specific parts of the text

Write stories or other compositions such as personal narrative, stories, and poetry, that employ a logical sequence of events, provide insight into why the incident is notable, and include details to develop the plot in English
Write expository compositions and reports that convey information from primary and secondary sources and use some technical terms
Write persuasive and expository compositions that include a clear thesis, describe organized points of support, and address a counter argument
Write in a variety of forms using effective word choice, structure, and sentence forms with emphasis on organizing logical arguments based on clearly related definitions, theses and evidence

Write in a variety of forms with an emphasis on persuasive forms (such as logical argument and expression of opinion) personal forms (such as response to literature, reflective essay, and autobiographical narrative) and literary forms such as, poems, plays and stories
W.7 Use multiple sources to extend writing
Record or dictate knowledge of a topic in a variety of ways, such as by drawing pictures, making lists, or using graphic organizers to show connections among ideas
Identify questions for investigating a given topic
Use print or technology resources to write a simple informative paper
Use accepted format (including quotation and reference notes) to credit sources of information
Develop questions to guide research
Collect information, take notes, and synthesize information on a given topic from a variety of sources
Formulate questions, refine topics, and clarify ideas
Compile written ideas and representations into reports, summaries or other formats and draw conclusions
W.8 Use tone and voice to engage specific audiences
Identify an audience for writing in English
Produce writing for given audiences and purposes in English
Write in a voice and style appropriate to audience and purpose
Exhibit an identifiable tone and voice in personal narratives and stories
